title: Clem Parberry
text:
Clement Hughes Parberry (December 30, 1911 – July 11, 1976) was an American coach and athletic administrator in <a href="Idaho">Idaho</a>, at the <a href="College%20of%20Idaho">College of Idaho</a> in <a href="Caldwell%2C%20Idaho">Caldwell</a> and the <a href="University%20of%20Idaho">University of Idaho</a> in <a href="Moscow%2C%20Idaho">Moscow</a>.
Born in <a href="Colorado%20Springs%2C%20Colorado">Colorado Springs, Colorado</a>, Parberry graduated from <a href="Pacific%20University">Pacific University</a> in <a href="Forest%20Grove%2C%20Oregon">Forest Grove, Oregon</a>. After coaching in <a href="Gooding%2C%20Idaho">Gooding, Idaho</a>, he became the athletic director at the College of Idaho in 1938, and its head coach in <a href="College%20football">football</a>, <a href="College%20basketball">basketball</a>, and <a href="College%20baseball">baseball</a>.
Parberry served in the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">U.S. Navy</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> and the <a href="Korean%20War">Korean War</a>, rising to the rank of <a href="Lieutenant%20commander%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant commander</a>. After his second tour ended in 1953, he joined the athletic staff at the University of Idaho as head <a href="Idaho%20Vandals%20baseball">baseball</a> coach and assistant in <a href="Idaho%20Vandals%20football">football</a> and <a href="Idaho%20Vandals%20men%27s%20basketball">basketball</a>. Previously, the head basketball coach at UI also led the baseball program, but increasing overlap between the seasons led to his hiring, taking over from <a href="Charles%20Finley%20%28coach%29">Charles Finley</a>.
Parberry led the Vandal baseball program for four seasons, then transferred to the physical education department; and <a href="Wayne%20D.%20Anderson">Wayne Anderson</a> succeeded him as head coach. Parberry ran the intramural program and retired from the university in 1975; he and his wife Viola and relocated to <a href="McCall%2C%20Idaho">McCall</a>, where they had owned and operated summer cabins on <a href="Payette%20Lake">Payette Lake</a> for decades. The following summer, Parberry died there of a heart attack at and is buried at the city cemetery.
A scholarship at the University of Idaho in physical education is awarded in his honor.
